page.title: 07Language
page.content: Many Dorset dialect words are still in use, especially among those who have always worked on the land. Cows still BLEARE (low) and they shelter in the LEW. A rogue beast is called a RAFTY ONE and this may also be applied to humans. Cattle are driven through DRONGWAYS or DRONGS (narrow lanes or passages). Bundles of sticks from hedge trimming are NITCHES and smaller kindling NICKIES. A tree stump with new growth is a MOCK, ants are EMMUTS and anthills EMMUT BUTS. Midmorning snack is a NAMMUT, a short length of drain is a BUNNY. A notch is a SNOTCH, smoke or dust is a SMUCK, a muddle is a HARDLE, apple or potato pulped is PUMMIED. NESH is soft and tender, SUANT is supple, workable. If you feel weak you are LEARY, something PLIMMED is swollen, and VLANKERS still fly from our bonfires.
